Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT29-COX 
    

      The Cox News Service spot news budget for Tuesday, September 29,
1998.
      c.1998 Cox News Service

   This is the Cox News Service spot news budget for Tuesday,
September 29, 1998. We will update this budget at 6 p.m. EDT.

   Separate feature and commentary budgets move at 10 a.m. EDT
Monday-Friday. Separate sports and business budgets move at 5 p.m.
EDT Monday-Friday.

   If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the
Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456. The night news editor, until 10
p.m. EDT, is Todd C. Duncan at 404-582-7282.

   With questions about Washington-originated material, please call
our Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338.

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316.

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   HURRICANE GEORGES

   GEORGES _ OCEAN SPRINGS, Miss. _ The Gulf Coast groaned under
the fury of Hurricane Georges, which moved ashore with gusts as
high as 172 mph early today as it spewed wind and rain from the
Florida Panhandle to Louisiana. New Orleans hoped it had avoided
the worst the storm could offer. No deaths or injuries had been
reported, but National Guard troops using trucks and boats had to
rescue about 200 people from flooded homes in the Florida
Panhandle, where most roads were reported flooded and Interstate 10
was washed out near the Alabama line. The hurricane's eye,
surrounded by wind blowing at a sustained 105 mph, moved ashore
this morning at Ocean Springs, between Biloxi and Pascagoula, and
the National Hurricane Service in Biloxi reported a gust to 172
mph. Within two hours, the wind started rising again at Pascagoula.
(Marlon Manuel in Mobile/Chris Burritt in Ocean Springs, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). WITH MAP

   w/photos. REFER TO MORE INSIDE.

   WITH

   BIGEASY _ NEW ORLEANS _ The Crescent City escaped the eye of
Hurricane Georges. Scene from the city. (Rochell, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   FLORIDA _ PENSACOLA _ Checking out the beach erosion and scene
along the Florida Panhandle. (Williams., Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). WITH MAP

   CANE _ PENSACOLA _ Report on damage from Georges in the
Panhandle. (Elmore, Palm Beach Post). 25.

   INTERNATIONAL

   CLINTON-MIDEAST _ WASHINGTON _ President Clinton will meet with
Israeli Prime Minister Bejamin Netanyahu and Palestinian Authority
President Yasser Arafat at the White House Monday, expected to
press for some small movement in the stalled Israeli-Paestinian
peace negotiations. Developing. (Deans, Cox News Service).

   EDs: To move by 6 p.m. EDT.

   NATIONAL

   TX-SUPREME-COURT _ WACO _ The Texas Supreme Court heard about
sex and corruption as it held the first session outside Austin in
more than 100 years, in a session at Baylor in Waco. (McCarthy,
Austin American-Statesman).

   LA-NINA _ Suddenly, more drought is in doubt. Officially, the
National Weather Service still is calling for a La Nina winter and
spring, which usually means drought for us. But UT aerospace
engineers monitoring satellite data from the eastern Pacific say
the signs there that, in June and July, forecast a developing La
Nina are flipflopping unpredicatbly. So it might be a normal winter
and spring for us, afterall. (Stanley, Austin American-Statesman).

   DEADBEATS _ Dayton was one of seven cities chosen for a national
study about unemployed fathers whose children are on welfare. The
study was only marginally successful, underscroing the difficulty
of reaching this hard-core group. (Hundley, Dayton Daily News). 12.

   RUDOLPH _ ANDREWS, N.C. _ FBI agents meet with bear hunters 7
p.m. Monday to discuss ways the hunters can help in the search for
bomb suspect Eric Robert Rudolph. (Chamberlain, AJC stringer; not
for use by NYT clients).

   TENGRAND _ At the urging of a suburban Atlanta police chief, and
with the intent to take a bite out of drug dealers' proceeds, U.S.
Sen. Max Cleland has introduced a bill that would make it possible
for police to seize the cash of anyone carrying more than $10,000.
The cash is deemed seizable if, among other things, whoever has it
``provided false information to any law enforcement officer,'' if
it is found ``in close proximity to a measurable quantity'' of any
illicit drug or if a drug dog ``alerts'' when sniffing it. Some
police organizations have praised the bill. But some police
officers have quietly raised objections to it, asserting that the
bill legislates an assumption of guilt about anyone carrying large
sums of cash and that innocent people whose cash is seized would
have to go to court and prove their innocence to get the money
back. We're looking for a worthy spokesperson to take the ``con''
side of the issue. (Payne, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   WASHINGTON

   SENIORS-SEX _ WASHINGTON _ The good news for middle-aged Baby
Boomers is that nearly three out of four sexually active older
Americans say sex is as good or better after 60 as it was in their
40s. The bad news is that fewer than half of all seniors are
sexually active. Those are some of the results of a national survey
on senior sex released Monday by the National Council on the Aging.
(Dart, Cox News Service).

   SCHOLARSHIPS _ WASHINGTON _ The Children's Scholarship Fund,
which underwrites private school scholarships for children in
kindergarten through eighth grade, announces Monday that Atlanta
and Dayton will be partner cities for the 1999 academic year.
(Monroe, Cox News Service 250).

   Eds: Separate stories will move to these two sites only.

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
